data.title: Slipping through the cracks
data.meta_description: Certain sports stories get lost in the hype of the Super Bowl and the National Football League. \n In case you missed it, here's what has caught my eye in the past couple of weeks. \n The St. Joseph's …
data.text:
Certain sports stories get lost in the hype of the Super Bowl and the National Football League.

In case you missed it, here's what has caught my eye in the past couple of weeks.

The St. Joseph's Hawks. I heard some Philadelphia sportswriters talking about how the city will never see a championship and everyone should just appreciate the journey. Hogwash I say.

This team will win a championship. They are experienced behind the leadership of senior Jameer Nelson and juniors Delonte West and Pat Carroll.

The Hawks almost won a game in the NCAA Tournament with a hobbled West last season. Nelson's the best player in the country and West helps form the best backcourt in the country. They are both shooting over 50 percent from the field and combine for 39 points a game. Yes, they don't have that dominant inside player, but everyone knows guard play wins in March. This team is special. Hop on the bandwagon right now.

The Flyers keep on winning and the Rangers keep on bringing in stars.

The Flyers don't have a Jaromir Jagr or Eric Lindros, but they have Ken Hitchcock. And the Flyers are currently second in the Eastern Conference standings.

Despite having a rash of injuries on defense and continuing question marks in goal, the Flyers keep on winning. But will that winning continue in May when stellar goalkeeping is a neccesity?

But at least they're not the Rangers. Lindros is nearing the end with his latest concussion and in desperate need of defense and goalkeeping, the Rangers went out and got Jagr.

Maybe he'll become the latest star to hang on too long in New York like Mark Messier, Wayne Gretzky and Lindros before him.

The 76ers are worse than last season and the Knicks are exciting again.

How is it that Philadelphia has an exciting center in Samuel Dalembert and a solid second scoring option in Glenn Robinson, but are losing more than they have in the past five years?

I guess coaching does count for something and without Larry Brown the 76ers are struggling. They don't play with the same heart and desire Brown's teams did and may actually not make the playoffs. The Knicks on the other hand have brought in Stephon Marbury, got rid of some dead weight, and are at the least bringing excitement back to the Garden. With general manager Isiah Thomas calling the shots, expect changes to continue in New York.

The Australian Open was the most exciting major for men's tennis in recent memory.

Andre Agassi and Andy Roddick both lost in thrilling five-set matches to unseeded Marat Safin. Roger Federer knocked off Lleyton Hewitt in an intense four-setter and eventually took over the No. — ranking.

The final was disappointing with a weary Safin no match for Federer. But both the Agassi and Roddick matches against Safin will go down as instant classics, and there were numerous exciting battles over the last two weeks. The only problem is ESPN televised the matches the next day. Maybe if the Aussie Open would be closer to April everyone would be a lot more interested.

—
